  223. amy October 7, 2016 at 1:12 PM

    Checking back in after a while here.

    Folks, this is difficult only if you’re really avoidant about math, allergic to planning, and assume you will never have to think about laws. But you live in a society with other people, so yeah, the math, planning, and thinking about laws is all mandatory.

    Once you have a child, control of your life is largely out of your hands until — if you’re lucky — the kid is 18. Until then, your days are about that child, even if the kid is good and rotten to you that day. And even if your kid isn’t in your house that day.

    A while back, I thought it’d be really nice to date again, so I tried it. And I found that every guy I met, no matter how nice in other ways, was kind of a jerk to my kid, and treated her like she was an inconvenience. So that’s it for men until she’s grown; I don’t need to keep exposing her to that. Her dad doesn’t feel the same way: he’s started seeing some flaky woman, and doesn’t like the woman’s kid. He tries to force the woman and our daughter together, which doesn’t make D happy and probably isn’t a ton of fun for the woman, either, and there he is being bad for the woman’s daughter. Because he doesn’t want to acknowledge that his turn doesn’t come again for several years. He wants to believe this time is about his maximum happiness, but it’s eroding his relationship with his daughter and probably hurting the other girl, too.

    Children, as I mentioned, are expensive. If you’re avoidant about the math, the court will do it for you. The court is not being unreasonable. If you make a ton, you can afford to share with your kid; if you don’t make a ton, you still have obligations to what’s a very large expense, whether or not it’s convenient for you, and whether or not it stops you from doing other things you want right then to do. These are things you need to be thinking about before you make the babies. And if you love a man who has expensive children, then you have a decision to make about how much you want to spend supporting him and his expensive children, and doing the difficult work of stepmothering. But it is very much your decision. Don’t go blaming the mom for it.

    I can tell you that children have eyes and ears and they know when one parent is ripping off another, or when one parent is enjoying themselves and hanging them, the kid, out to dry. Don’t think they don’t see it. And they’ll remember it for the rest of their lives. So — do the right thing. Not in whatever way is convenient to what you want, but the actual right thing. Yes, it may mean you don’t marry that nice person who wants to have a baby when the reality is that neither of you can afford it. Because you already have a kid you’re obliged to, and that was your choice when you took those pants off.

    And the reality is you’re lucky. If your kid(s) had disabilities, that’d lock down the rest of your life. The rest of your life would be about looking after your disabled kids and their care. I have friends like that and you probably do too.

    As for not having custody: most states now favor shared care if it’s a reasonable thing to do and the parents want it. If it’s not reasonable, it’s usually because the parents live far apart or because they can’t get along well enough to coordinate that far. (Sometimes one parent’s a criminal.) If that’s the case, then that’s the case. But before you marry the man and hook up to his finances, take a careful look at why he doesn’t have custody. He probably didn’t get tricked. And if he really did get tricked, then take an even harder look, because this is a man who doesn’t take care of important legal business the way he should, even when it has to do with his children.

    So before you complain more, back up, take a look at what homework you failed to do before getting yourself into high-stakes situations, and then don’t do that again.

    1. Gemma October 18, 2016 at 4:45 PM

      The truth sometime theres a exwives really cruel to their exhusbands even the father is doing his responsibility to his child as he can.like my husband ex I am really good to his ex but she is really crazy.

  224. CA mama October 30, 2016 at 10:51 PM

    It really upsets me when I hear the word cheater or cheated. For example I was married for 23 years had for children and lived with a man that was verbally abusive towards the children and towards myself. All those years since my babies were born I did everything for them while he did nothing for example wouldn’t help feed them when help change your diapers wouldn’t help bathe them, all he did as they got older was take them to baseball and thought that he was the best father for doing that. As the boys got older I still continue doing everything taking them to school showing up for teacher. Conferences by myself dealing with teachers dealing with school projects while he sat at his computer chair surfing the Internet. I continue to care for them doctors appointments dentist appointments staying up late with them at night when I had fevers and were crying why he stayed in bed, OK we both have full-time jobs the whole time except for when he was laid off four times for calling in sick too many times . Continued working and supporting the family and continued doing everything for my children . Over the years everything became a challenge I had to cook dinner and think what are we going to eat every night when I got to feed my family every night after working eight hours , and you think he would help out no he did not . I had to make his lunches every night for work if I didn’t he would threaten that he would quit his job. He never helped with laundry he never help do the dishes , when the household was noisy he would stomp his feet upstairs for me to keep the boys quiet. He was very controlling and demanding and quite difficult to deal with . I tried to leave him once after five years but he begged for me to come back and he would help me with i’ll kids and just be part of the family . He never like to go anywhere with this all rather just stay home .
    So you could see how over the years I would become resentful of him and started falling out of love with him .
    Now I’m not bashing man but I think there are some wonderful Caring Men out there . That want a family and wouldn’t take them for granted .
    The most disturbing part is his belittling the kids even when they became teenagers. I argued with him so many times to stop belittling our kids . I know he loves them all but he doesn’t know how to treat them . He was just an angry Person that just hates everyone . And your pie wonder why I stayed so long well that was because I couldn’t get out he brought my self-esteem down so low that I became depressed .
    I’m 52 years old now and on my boys are range from 15 to 23 , when I turned 50 something happened to me I started menopause and I grew a pair of balls and I family found the strength to leave him .
    Now remember our kids are teenagers and older and I can’t just take them with me because they have their own minds but they’ve been so used to this way of living that they do not know any better . Cussing was part of their everyday life being talked to was part of their normal verbage. The day I left that day I found the street to leave and when I left I knew I was never going back to him . I felt the relief from my back instantly lift off that I didn’t have to We in the same home as him . But the worst thing that happened after all this was that my boys Thought that I left them because I never came back home I’m still in the same town actually couple miles away that’s it at my parents home because I had nowhere else to go . He begged me to come back home but I did not I could not . So he began building is thawed up in our kids his head that I left them but I left them all to go be with another man , which in this case I did meet someone else . But I tell you the marriage was over for years and he knew it . He has put in our boys his mind that I left them and him for another man that I cheated . So my boys think I’m a cheater well this is what I explain to them . That I did not leave them I only left their father which I didn’t expect them to understand because they don’t know anything about relationship . I also explained them that I left their father if I cheated I would’ve went back to the father then they get all call me a cheater . But when someone leaves and never comes back that’s called your mom left your father and is never coming back to him .
    So six months after I left him he filed for legal separation so we can collect child support that’s what he said . So I had a good job making more money than him I end up having to pay him $1035 every month for two teenage boys . I don’t have a problem paying for them that amount of money definitely changed my financial situation . I could pay the bills anymore he couldn’t pay the bills anymore I had no choice but to file bankruptcy to clear myself from debt that was my only relief since my income changed .
    I do have 20% custody of the two teenage boys but with their father’s influence they don’t want to see me at all . Like I said he has them convinced that I left them know matter how many times I’ve told them that I did not leave them I’m right here and always will be right here he has influence them to hate me . I understand this is all hard for them and they see their father sad and I want to protect him . But for me raising them since the day they were born all the way up to teenagers and doing everything for them has been very difficult for me living without them . They don’t understand and everyone keeps telling me to let them be and when they grow up and have relationships of their own they will understand but in the meantime I’m losing years with them that is very painful . I know they’re in pain for not having me with them every day but again they are taking their dad’s influence and staying away from me . Over the year and a half things changed at my job my Pay became less and so I took him to court to do a child support modification , yes I pay less support now but at the same time I don’t have enough money to live on my own so I’m still at my parents house at 52 years old . Feels pretty sad . He does not want to give me the divorce so he’s dragging things on I had to get rid of my attorney and hire a new one to make something happen .
    We own a home and we’re still paying on and just waiting to move forward with that process .
    Every day I wonder if I should’ve went back to him just for the sake of the kids no matter how unhappy I was with him . I did seek some counseling and every time was told that this was a controlling person and I would just do more harm to myself to go back to him. My boys they just want me back home with them but for me to do that I would have to have a relationship their father which of course we would expect a sexual relationship and I can not put myself with him anymore as my love for their father does not exist any longer . He wants me to suffer and have nothing from the house but I know California is a no-fault state and I did respond to his legal separation with a divorce irreconcilable differences .
    I feel marriage is a one time thing but when there is belittling in the home year after year after year after year and there is no acception . My biggest mistake was not to leave when the kids were younger it would’ve been less painful on them and everyone . I think it’s easy if your kids are older to divorce but it’s not it’s worse . I don’t wish divorce or separation on anyone but to live unhappy for so long for so many reasons that’s why there is divorce . Once you start paying child support never get married again until your obligations are over because it will eat you up. Or stay married make the best of it until those kids are over 18. You only have one life if you’re not happ change it and make it happy.
    In my story I’m not putting any Man or woman down. I’m just sharing from my experience .
    Please excuse any typos and if I’ve said too much I apologize.
    Ty

  225. Angela November 16, 2016 at 4:57 AM

    This is a very sensitive subject, but we are all just trying to get by the best way possible. What else is there to do? It is not easy, and emotions can run high. It happens in our household everyday…
    My boyfriend has 5 children with 2 other women. He makes a good living, but we are struggling to pay rent, feed OUR family, put gas in the cars, pay bills and just plain exist without killing each other.
    I am a full time student, raising our 5 month old son, and my daughter and son from my first marriage. Taking care of the house, cooking, cleaning, laundry etc.
    He pays $1500 every month in child support! His 2 youngest get $800 and the older 3 $700.
    I get child support as well, but a measly $400/ month for both of my children.
    He literally pays rent and half our bills (I help with the other half) and we are broke for the month. Left with nothing but a lot of stress. I can’t help but have a little resentment pent up inside. Especially when the other moms are smoking, drinking, eating out, and buying things for themselves. I buy my kids nice clothes and will hand them down to his kids because they come over wearing Walmart clothes with holes in them! Goodness it upsets me!
    I’m going back to school to get my degree and a better paying career. If I work on top of this, the crazy daycare costs will end up settling us back even further! Not to mention the gas to get me there and back.
    Our relationship is hurting because of all this financial stress. My kids see and hear our arguments. We both are trying so hard and want to raise our son under the same roof and eventually get our heads above water. When is that though, 13 years from now?
    It’s awful of me to say this, but at times I consider the fact my kids and I would be better off on our own instead of picking up the pieces of his past. the system has it so a single mom with kids can live more comfortably than we are now. I already know this because before meeting him I worked full time and the state helped me out with everything! Food, medical insurance, childcare. It’s just sad we are at the point we are, and stressing out so much we can’t even enjoy each other.

It just seems wrong to me, I would never take the kids away from their mothers and then ontop of that force them to pay me money. The whole system just seems so unfair and sad to me. I cannot see any reason a young man would ever want to have kids because the whole system is stacked against him.

  230. KDH January 29, 2017 at 12:56 AM

    I sat here and fell down the rabbit hole of these comments and nearly 400 comments later…I have questions.

    1. Many of these complaints from new wives/stepmothers/dads mention the child’s mother’s new husband/boyfriend having a certain job or income. If you don’t think the step mom’s income should factor in, then why should the step dad (the child’s mother’s partner) be an issue. So what if he has a 200k job and moved them in his penthouse? That was his choice. And if he thinks baby mama shouldn’t work, that’s between the two of them and the Lord. But if you don’t want your coins counted, you can’t count his. What if he’s keeping his assets separate, just like you are?

    2. Among the ridiculous things I’ve read, the idea that you get some choices about things like extracurricular activities and braces are the weirdest. No, our child doesn’t have to pick and choose because we couldn’t work our adult issues out. If she needs braces, pony up your half; she’s not going to be bucktoothed because you don’t agree she’s bucktoothed. Yes, our child still plays sports. If we were married, you’d be running up and down the damn sideline and the court, but now it’s basketball OR football OR soccer? Nope. It’s all of them.

    3. Many women sought to pit their husbands first children against the second children. If you know good and damn well your boyfriend/husband already has an astronomical child support responsibility, why, praytell, did ya’ll have more children? He’s barely able to finance the ones he has, but you thought it was smart to have…more? No, my child doesn’t have to suffer because you and him are making poor choices. My child’s costs didn’t evaporate because you had more kids.

    The idea that a man would not spend 60% of his income on his child if they were together is sad. Like…would he really be spending 10% and going on a monthly Tahitian vacation? Probably not. My parents spent nearly all of their take home pay of their children, in theory. Their housing costs would’ve been smaller without us, so we cost more there. Food costs more because of us. And insurance and clothing and…everything. When you’re a parent, the bulk of your income goes to children. So yes, your child support helps pay rent and lights and gas and car notes. Because the custodial parent would have cheaper rent, less electricity, less gas and would have less wear and tear on the car were it not for your kids. You have to pay your share of that too. The custodial parent has less opportunity for overtime and extra income because they’re taking care of kids. So that’s a loss of potential wages. They leave work and stay home with sick children, also affecting wages. They have less physical freedom. Say you have the kids 2 days a week, you have 5 to be leisurely, work more hours, explore hobbies, gain more training. The custodial parent has 2 days.
    If the mother was out of the workforce, at your request or agreement, she’s now missed on years for SSI and is generally less employable than a woman with no lapses in her resume. So having primary custody in general, but in some cases, more so for a woman, isn’t financially advantageous. But your kids are more than dollars and cents. That said, struggle isn’t a badge of honor. If you’re proud that you never made the custodial parent pay their portion of the responsibility you BOTH took on at conception, I’m not sure what to say there. You

    If she doesn’t work or you feel like she’s underemployed, she’s a gold digger. But if she makes a good living, she doesn’t need child support. If she remarries, she and her new spouse should be able to take care of your children. But if he takes too good care of them, they don’t need child support. They went on a cruise! They have iPhones! But if you remarry, your new wife shouldn’t be part of the equation. You don’t think you should have to pay insurance, though someone probably did when you were with the mother and it probably was you. I don’t get it. Many of the men who responded make it seem as though they didn’t pay bills at all when they were with their children’s mother. You didn’t pay rent/housing then? Utilities?Transportation? Taxes? Childcare? I’ll bet the rest went to expenses for your kids. WELL GUESS WHAT…same thing buddy!

    There was even a primer on how to be a scofflaw and evade arrest and child support! But the thing is, if one were clever enough to pull of such a ruse..they’d have figured out how to use a condom.

    1. Mel June 10, 2017 at 1:42 PM

      Brilliant!!! The double standards you noted are particularly entertaining.

    1. alain smithee July 24, 2017 at 11:48 AM

      My family court judge disagrees with me, but since it takes two people to create a child, providing for that child’s NEEDS should be a shared responsibility.

      On the other hand, Her Honor (sarcasm intended) feels that the children (and by inference, the custodial parent and their …paramour) are entitled to a government mandated LIFESTYLE.

      The other problem are the financial incentives in the Child Support Performance and Incentive Act that reward states with kickbacks for collecting the maximum amount of child support possible. This creates financial incentives to both order sole custody with the lower earning parent and to restrict the children’s access to the non-custodial parent. Both of these actions increase the amount of direct (cash) child support collected.

      And since Her Honor does not have the …political courage to enforce my access to my children, I feel like my ex-wife’s indentured servant who is damned lucky to be allowed to visit with my children at my ex-wife’s whim.

  237. shaun September 1, 2017 at 10:22 PM

    I understand it’s frustrating to pay child support when it feels as if “she” is taking “his” hard earned money. That kind of mentality will always leave you feeling angry and victimized. Here’s the reframe from a custodial parent’s perspective.

    As a custodial parent, child support doesn’t even come close to paying for the actual cost of raising a child. When my ex and I were married 100% of both our incomes went to our kids. We lived in a dual income household and did everything in their best interest. We never argued about splitting the costs for our family 50-50. We were in it together. Then we got divorced. That 100% he used to contribute is now 25%, significantly less. Guess whose percentage didn’t change – mine. Because I’m the custodial parent. 100% of my time, energy, mental effort and income still go to my kids. Let’s do some theoretical math to highlight the energy expenditures here and monetize time to see how valuable it is and where “mom” and “dad” might stand.

    He sees our boys every other weekend; he’s bummed to not be a part of their daily life but happy with the arrangement thus far. Let’s say he got them every weekend, just for the sake of argument – we’ll be generous with dad and say he has more hands on time.

    Where he used to have to parent with mom 100% of the time, now he parents only 30% of the time. Mind you this is weekend time. It’s the best shift. It’s not during the week when all the work has to be done, all the school work, extracurriculars, dr’s appts, etc … you get the picture.

    Mom on the otherhand must parent 70% of my time.

    According to salary.com a mom is worth $143k in labor. Let’s say a dad is worth just as much as it relates to labor.

    If we divide $143k by 12 to get a monthly figure and then multiply it by .3, we find that dad’s contribution is worth $3.5k in labor per month parenting on the weekend (lol – the easiest time to parent – it should be worth less, that’s when all the fun happens).

    By the same formula, Mom contributes $8.3K in labor per month, parenting 70% of the time.

    So mom contributes in this scenario, more than twice as much labor and 100% of her actual income. Dad contributes 30% of the parenting labor and has downgraded from 100% of actual earned income to only whatever percentage the state mandates (significantly less than 100%).

    Do you see why counting numbers is a bad practice; it puts everyone in the victim box depending on where you stand. Worst of all it treats the children as objects of resentment.

    Parenting is tough when you’re married. It’s a fuck load tougher when you divorce.

    Divorce sucks for everyone, it’s financially stressful to split a household in two. Being resentful about percentages and money – solves absolutely nothing. Your partner had a life before you that he still needs to take care of. It’s complicated but it’s the fact of the matter. And you chose to be married to him knowing this full well. Every situation is unique but for the most part – both parents are hustling to just provide for their children. As a woman standing on the opposite end of the stick – I can promise you, most of us are not living a lavish life funded by our ex husbands. We’re just trying to fill the gap when he once stood.

    We all have to remind ourselves that conscious choices were made and for each of those choices comes a responsibility. It is not an “us” v “them” thing and if it is you’re doing it wrong. It’s an “us” for “them” – us being the parents, them being our kids. The ones who never asked to be brought into this, the ones who still deserve to be provided for.

    When you can start to see that your husband is not a victim and that this situation is of his own doing and that the support is paid for the kids – you’ll start to see things with less anger, resentment, and victimization and more for what they are – two people just trying to take care of their kids in a complicated situation.

  238. 1quan October 5, 2017 at 10:28 PM

    Woh woh woh hold up a minute are you people really complaining that your partner is paying for his kids. How much the custodial parent pays is irrelevant just like your income is too. The non custodial parent shouldnt be limited to what needs to be paid just because the other parent who mind you is also physical and mentally caring or there child makes. Now i will agree 60 percent is steep but i see people complaining about 30 percent. He would be paying for his kids if he was still with the other parent so just becuase they are no longer together that shouldnt change anything . I make decent money and i will be making the ex pay for at least 40 percent since im not only paying the other half but it isnt easy to care for kids as a single parent picking up and dropping off at school. Doctors, sick time, and all that other emotional stuff is super draining

  239. ZAHale November 28, 2017 at 7:16 AM

    Well…I speak from experience. The Weld County Court in Colorado reduced me to a second class citizen and effectively circumvented the Constitution and made me a wage slave. I dared to divorce my abusive ex wife. She filed false charges against me in response, admitted to lying about it in court, and the judge let her take my daughter out of state. I was ordered to pay child support, or else I would lose my license, lose my professional certifications, and go to jail.

    This is slavery. Pure and simple. Either you work and give us your money, or we subject you to cruel and unusual punishments (a violation of the 17th amendment, and the 6th amendment). If you don’t pay, they will deprive you of your property and this can happen whether you are actually notified or not (Violation of the 4th and 5th amendments).

    Now, I work a job that pays 14 an hour. I got a 2% raise back in July. Last week, the company jacked up my insurance rates by 33%. I already paid 300 a month in child support. Combine that with the insurance for my daughter, I am paying 500 a month. Then add in my monthly medication costs of 200 dollars. For the bills? Well, I pay 80 a month for phone/internet service, 500 a month for housing, 150 a month for utilities (gas, water, electric), 105 a month for vehicle Insurance, 200 a month in fuel to get to and from work. I limit my monthly food allowance to 250 dollars. I end up rationing for half of every month. I have only 255 dollars to get by, and if an emergency vehicle repair or medical issue comes up, I am completely fucked. And there is nothing I can do about it.

    This is the grim reality of it all. Nothing will change until the men that are being subjected to this form of legalized slavery revolt against the system that allows it to continue. I am also a veteran. This is not what I swore to defend…putting a stop to tyrannical regimes is what I signed up for, and now, I live every day with the boot of the tyrants on my neck.

    A lot of men in my position are killing themselves. I mean that literally. Their blood is on the broken child support system’s hands. Everyone who is involved with the operations of these programs nation wide is directly responsible for the deaths of these father’s that were crushed by the weight of a system that was built specifically to destroy them. I hold the state governments and the courts responsible for their deaths. But, they won’t kill me. I am gonna do whatever I can to absolutely destroy the system that is in place. This system does nothing but hurt the children, and destroys any relationship they may have with their fathers.

    It’s really simple.

    If you don’t want to be involved with child support, do not, repeat, do not have children, and do not hook up with a man who owes child support.

    Do not play the game of trying to get custody so you can evade c/s, either. It’s unlikely to work, but it is likely to be expensive and destructive all around. And don’t take it out on the kid, either, or talk down the mom because the dad has a responsibility. All you’ll do is screw that child up and make things harder for her at home.

    I don’t know what to tell you. Kids cost money to raise. A kid in modest circumstances will cost about a quarter-million by the time she’s 18, and that doesn’t even touch college.

    I’ll just say it again: if you cannot accept the realities of child support and college payments with good grace, do not tangle with a divorced dad of a minor child. No, don’t tell me about your right to love. That’s not going to change anything up there.

    You should however consider that if *he* is complaining about the ex and the support, and talking like it’s not fair, you should imagine your own name instead of the ex’s in that conversation.   243. Teresa December 23, 2017 at 8:01 AM

    Child support is such a touchy subject and normally I keep out of it, but I’m now having to deal with it myself… I never thought I’d ever file for CS but when my son’s father couldn’t be reasoned with I realized that CS was the only way I could go. I understand that guys and their new family believe that CS is unfair and unreasonable but your not the one struggling to support a child that you thought you would be raising with their father. My son is only 20 months old and for 16 months of that I did it solely on my on own. I was doing really well until I had to quit my job do to not having someone to watch my son. I couldn’t afford child care and everyone I had lined up in case something happened with the previous babysitter all fell through. Yes I’m on FS, Medicaid, and living in government assistant housing but that doesn’t mean I can afford child care.. It’s super expensive and I was making 9$ a hour. So due to that I have been out of work for almost 4 months. I was able to make my savings last about a month 1/2, but my son’s needs don’t stop just cuz my income does.. So for the first time since he was born I had to ask his father to help.. Let’s just say he was as controlling as ever but at that point I really didn’t have a choice. I begged him to be reasonable about things but he wouldn’t have any of it. Well about a month or 2 ago I decided that enough was enough (with the talks from people telling me I should) I filed for child support. Man if he wasn’t pissed, telling me that it was BS, that he didn’t need this kinda added stress on him and that he would rather sign his rights away and never see his son again then deal with CS. I was blown away and in tears at hearing that. Like always it was all about him and what it was doing to him.. Nothing about his son and his needs. I have heard a number of reasons why I should drop it and each one let’s me know he was lying about the last reason. Every conversation he makes sure he brings up the CS. I’m trying to be nice but he’s starting to really piss me off with his selfishness. I know why he’s being this way and it’s cuz he has a new GF who is currently about 15 weeks pregnant with his child. He feels that he should be able to pay me what he feels is fare and have the rest for his new family, but I feel like that is messed up. He has only saw our son about 20 times since he was born and since I filed he has refused to see him to hurt me. It’s been over a month. I guess since he saw being cruel and mean to me wasn’t going to get me to drop it he is starting to be nice but that isn’t going to get me to do what he wants either. He just doesn’t get it it’s not about him or me, it’s about our son and what’s best for him. I have finally gotten the help I need with child care and have a great job that I most likely will get. I am very honest with him and told him it pays pretty well and his first response was ” Well now you can drop CS “. WTH is wrong with him!!!!! No I will not be dropping it now or in the future. I have spent thousands of dollars on our son with him only giving me 200$ and that’s me being nice about it. I love spending money on my son but I’ll be damned if my son grows up seeing his father’s second child get everything while he gets only what his mother can afford being a single mom… It’s not always about how much but it sure as hell will be fair and if I have to go through the courts to get it then I damn sure will. I have no sympathy for a father having to pay any amount of child support. If you didn’t want to take care of a child fairly then make sure you take precautions to make sure it doesn’t happen. The next women that comes into the picture if you don’t like it then leave and if you don’t it’s not the ex’s or child’s problem. As for my ex’s GF and unborn, well this is going to sound mean, but we don’t care about that either, it’s not our problem. So before people judge a mother for filing for CS get your facts straight and stop always listening and believing the father or his knew family… Sometimes they are just mad and resentful for having to pay what is owed to the child that came before!!!!

  244. Nikki_Insight January 16, 2018 at 1:58 PM

    There are 2 sides to every coin…
    First, I am a single mother who envies those women who actually receive any form of child support in helping to raise their child(ren) because children aren’t free and it takes a huge tole on one person’s finances to have to take on all the financial burden of raises a child on their own. But, that’s not how I go to this post, so let me flip the coin…

    I have a boyfriend and we are madly in love with each other. The only thing standing in the way of me making a firm decision that there is a future with him is the fact that he owes a substantially amount of CS and as a result all of his paychecks are cut in half. He cannot live off of the remaining portion of his check, let alone to save for things like… a car, a home, etc. He basically HAS TO live with someone else because he cannot afford to get his own place. He was stable (holding it together) when we met, but when his roomy had issues, that’s when his personal financial status came to light. Prior to his roomy having issues, we had talking about getting a place together. But after his true financial situation got revealed, I am hesitant to combine our resources. Because, he basically has none. And on top of that, I am very careful with money. I don’t spend money that I do not have and I always pay my bills first. So, if money is tight and low, I adjust my lifestyle accordingly. He on the other hand is not very money conscious at all. And I don’t want to tell a man what to do with HIS money, but if you know that you have limited cash, it only seems logical to me that you have to cut the unimportant things out of your life, like cigarettes and marijuana. Yet, those are things which he buys on a regular basis_ like daily. Additionally, he drives across town when we (really me) are low on gas. And who is replacing the gas that he uses for unimportant trips? Me.

    To the outsider, it looks like he is using me, but what you don’t realize is that he was stable when I met him. I also did not have a car when I met him. He spent money on me and never asked me for anything. I would have never known his financial status if his roomy hadn’t went south. Basically, he depended on his roomy paying their half of the bill. When the roomy became unstable then it drastically affected his life because due to his reduced check, he only makes enough to live at bare minimum.

    I love him profusely but I feel that his money issue will always be the demise of our relationship if we take it to the next level (as in marriage). I wish that he did’t have this burden of paying child support, but I don’t feel sorry for or sympathize with him or any of the other men here on that face the same issue because…

    On the flip side of the coin… I am a single mother (of 2) who has never received child support. What I do receive is a heavy financial burden of having to raise children on my own_ with no help from the other sexual participant of this ordeal. I feel (though I may be wrong) that garnishment is the result of a man ignoring his responsibility in the matter and needing the state to get involved is the reprecussuion. A simplier/more reasonible solution would be for the man (sometimes woman) to step up and help out voluntarily no matter what rift raft may or may not exist with the other parent. Bottom-line, children are not free. To think that you should continue to enjoy the freedom of keeping all of your income while the other parent forks the expenses of raising your offspring is simply selfish to me. It doesn’t stop me from loving the man who has put himself in this place. But I can’t feel sorry for him either because as a single parent baring all the weight/expenses_ living (3 bdr vs studio), eating ($200/week vs $50), transportation, education, clothes, misc house supplies x3, every regular expense X3… Not to mention the time you no longer have because your life outside work is taking care of your children. I simply can’t feel sorry for someone who does not initiate support and as a result, has to be court-mandated.

    I apologize for the brutal honesty but in many cases (as is with my boyfriend who owes $45K in CS), you brought this on yourself. I’m paying a chunk of my check every week to take care of my children and the expenses of having them, the only difference is that it is not court-mandated. It is just me being a parent and that means owning up to my responsibilities. I don’t have the luxury of putting myself first and ignoring the fact that I have children in this world. But many men (some women too) do it all the time and are upset when the state catches up with them and forces them to man-up.

    And when I met him and fell in love, I didn’t realize that his ex was such a monster.

  249. illmatic March 6, 2018 at 12:09 AM

    The nonsense here, is the argument that the child support amount is not sufficient to cover the expenses of the custodial parent. Referring specifically to “Amy” who seems to be really bitter and self righteous. Consider a father who’s paying $800 a month in child support. Now, add to that the cost of medical insurance, so another $150-$250 a month and so now we’re up to roughly $1000 a month. Now assuming standard visitation of every other weekend, lets add another $100 a weekend for food and entertainment, now we’re up to $1300-$1500 a month realistically, on a child support order of $800 a month, and that doesn’t include other incidentals and what not. Yet, it some peoples minds that STILL not enough? Instead of knocking good decent NCP’s who don’t think they should be footing the bill for the ex’s luxury car or new house, which we all know realistically is being paid for by the CS, maybe the CS should be treated just like public assistance, put it on a debit card that can ONLY be used for food and clothing, no cash withdraw option either, or make it one blanket system under federal guidelines instead of up to the states, because as it is, the CP’s are making out like bandits, and the NCP’s get the shaft.

  251. jon deaux July 27, 2018 at 4:06 PM

    See if the judge will allow the parents to use a child support trust account in the form of a special purpose checking account like this (https://www.mediate.com/articles/if_they_can_do_parenting_plans.cfm).

    This would provide accountability and help make sure that the child support is actually being used to provide for the children instead of being treated as additional family income that the custodial parent can spend any way they damned well please.

    In my state, parents are supposed to split the transportation costs for visitation. If my guess is correct, and you are paying all of the visitation costs, then I would ask the court to order the custodial parent to allow the noncustodial parent to claim the children as dependents for tax purposes in order to pay for the travel expenses associated with visitation.

    If the noncustodial parent now has or has ever had a child support arrears, I would ask what interest rate the courts have ordered the noncustodial parent to pay on the child support arrears. Federal law [42 US Code 654(21)(a)] caps the amount of interest that states can charge on child support arrears at 6-percent simple interest. If the custodial parent was charged more than 6-percent interest on their child support arrears, then this may have made him overpay child support, and he may be due a refund.

    The courts are also SUPPOSED to consider the paying parent’s ability to pay child support, but my experience has been that courts are more concerned with increasing the gross amount of child support collected, because that increases the federal kickbacks that states receive for collecting child support under the Child Support Performance and Incentive Act.

    English judge Sir William Blackstone described child support as being for the care and maintenance of the children, but my experience has been that courts are more interested in treating custodial parents as indentured servants by forcing the paying parent to provide a government mandated lifestyle for the children, and by inference, the custodial parent. We also won’t get started on the lack of visitation enforcement by ‘family’ courts. I’ve learned to consider myself to be damned lucky to be allowed to visit with my children at my ex-wife’s whim.

    And yes, the contact information is fictitious because my family court judge is not happy with me. It has something to do with my having proven her wrong several times without my having a law degree. I also write my legislators regularly about these issues.

    1. Denise December 10, 2018 at 1:31 PM

It is not fair that child support can get so hight not caring about the expenses and necessities of the father working so hard for him and his new family not to have anything and top of that live in debt their lives because the other woman does not want to arrange anything and she decides that 1000 a month is just enough for one kid. I mean what type of kid spends 1000 dollars a month if she doesn’t have to pay anything not insurance not day care

    2. jon deaux April 12, 2019 at 9:25 PM

      Some states have laws allowing courts to order an accounting to make sure that the child support is actually spent on the children. This may be worth investigating. Some states also have laws making misappropriation of child support a criminal offense, which you could use to get the court to give your husband custody of the children in exchange for not pressing criminal charges against the ex-wife and her …paramour.

      If the court will allow you to use a Child Support Trust Account in the form of a shared checking account like this one (https://www.mediate.com/articles/if_they_can_do_parenting_plans.cfm), it would also help keep your husband’s ex-wife from treating the child support as additional income that she can spend any way she damned well pleases.

      As I stated in a previous post, Federal law [654(21)(a)] limits the amount of interest that states can charge on child support arrears. If your husband was ordered to pay more than 6-percent interest on any past child support arrears, you should ask the prosecutors office about any interest that your husband may have paid on his child support payments, and have the prosecutors office recalculate the interest charges using the rate specified by Federal law, not state law or local court rules. If the court charged less than 6-percent, I would not ask for a recalculation.

      And no, I’m not a lawyer. I’ve just dealt with too many sleazy, unethical lawyers, and I’ve learned how they think.

      Good luck.

    3. Some1real2u June 5, 2019 at 12:51 PM

      IF you did not go for child support that’s your fault and your decision. Don’t expect another woman to forfit what their CHILDREN are entitled to because you feel like they should be like you. You got with a man with that amount of child support. YOU made that choice. Now live with it.

  254. Cindy October 27, 2018 at 12:29 AM

    My ex is a user. He is currently underpaying in child support and still giving me hell about it. It is not court ordered but what he agreed to give and I am trying to keep the peace while struggling and running through my savings to make up the difference.

    BUT, he resents that he has to pay ANYTHING at all for his child and constantly reminds me of it and always uses it against me. He’s refused to put her on his health insurance and I’m not going to be able to much longer, so we’re probably going to have to get on assistance and he’ll be forced to pay it through the courts. I don’t know how we’re going to deal with him then.

    He makes almost 2.5X what I earn btw, but it goes through his hands like water because he never knew how to budget in the first place and priorities fishing and shopping trips over utility bills.

    Last week, he tried to lower his support even more and bullied me about it and I told him that would leave me no choice but to put him on court ordered child support, and he told me I was threatening him. He doesn’t realize that a mother does not need to make threats, she can simply go file. He fails to see that the mere fact that I haven’t filed says a lot. But instead he twists my words as if I’m just some money-hungry woman looking to ruin him and his girlfriend. He’s a true narcissist who thinks the world owes him something for nothing.

    I’m sure some of you dads who think you relate to him just because he’s a man paying child support probably think I’ve done something wrong. Nope. Never cheated, scammed, hit, abused, or remotely tried to hurt him. The most I’ve ever done to him was stand up to his abuse, which he would have none of.

    But if you were smart, you would never compare yourself to this monster. I’m sure some of you new wives think that he should not have to pay anything but I find it ridiculous that a man wants to cut his $200/mo into half just because he can do it.

    He is the worst but I still can’t hurt him. I see a lot comments about cutthroat ex wives ruining these guys and I wonder why he can’t count his blessings?

    If I have to go on state assistance or if I run out of savings, I’m not going to have any choice but to get a support order. Then things will get even worse. I wish I had the cajones these ex wives have.

    Cindy

  255. Kat November 4, 2018 at 9:01 AM

    All of you “step parents” complaining that your husband is paying so much support; I’m going to break it down for you so it’s simple to understand (as the ex receiving support).
    1) you knew when you chose to break up his family and marry him that he would have to pay support.
    2) kids are expensive and the custodial parent has a lot of weight on her shoulders. She has to work one or two jobs and still come home and help kids with homework, prepare meals, clean the house, do laundry, get 2-3 hours of sleep then wake up and do it all over again. She deserves some help!
    3) none of you complaining seem to comprehend that kids are expensive. I’m going to use my situation as an example; I receive 1090 child support for three kids, his wife complains he pays too much and they struggle. I work two full time jobs, so daycare is 45$ a day for 3 kids that’s 135$ per DAY! On daycare alone!!!!! 50% of that should be his responsibility to pay, half of the monthly costs of daycare is 2025$!!! I pay 4050 a month of daycare! Just daycare!!!!! His little 1090 he pays a month is NOT enough to even pay half the daycare!
    Now, let’s look at bills: at home it is me and 3 children a total of 4 people. He’s responsible for half the bills his 3 kids help create. The mortgage is 1000, 3/4 of that (the kids share since they live there) is 750$. Half of that 750 is HIS responsibility so that’s another 375 he should be paying in addition to his half of daycare of 2025, so now he is up to 2375$ he should pay but only pays 1090 and his ex is still complaining. Add another 250 for the kids share of the electric bill, water bill, cable bill, WiFi bill, another 600 a month for his half of the groceries they eat, none of that is factoring in clothes, shoes, extracurricular activities, medical care costs etc etc! Really he should be paying almost 5000 a month for 3 kids but court can only grant 1090 because his income is lower than mine. He refuses to get a better job or work 2 jobs like I am forced to do to pick up his slack, and the new wife doesn’t work at all yet wants to complain about him paying “sooooo much”

    Please lol trust me the guys paying support are the ones getting off easy! The custodial parent typically is not getting 50% like she should!

    1. Non Custodial Mom December 11, 2018 at 11:42 AM

      Here’s what people aren’t understanding. YES a parent should be responsible and pay for their child/ren but it shouldn’t be all about one parent doing it all. If it takes TWO to make a child it sure as hell should be TWO incomes (especially in today’s economy).

      My situation is this. I pay over $700 a month in CS plus medical for 2 kids. I have another child who lives with me and my husband. My ex never uses the money he gets from me for the children. They always have clothes that look disheveled or not the right size, never have winter coats or boots, barely keeps minimal food in the house etc. yet always seems to be driving a nice vehicle and is always going out on “dates” and treating his girlfriends. That’s another issue is that he is NEVER home to be with the kids. On top of my CS and medical that I pay I still go and buy them the essentials that he FAILS to provide even though as sole custodian receiving CS and working a full time job you should be providing. Then on top of that I STILL have a third child to raise and a mortgage payment, and the same damn water, electric, internet, phone, gas, car payment, daycare etc. as he does yet none of that is taken into consideration when figuring out CS.

      In my experience, there are losers who get out of taking care of their kids BUT there are also losers that are money hungry selfish assholes that think they shouldn’t be responsible for anything. Either way the kids get the brunt of it and it sucks either way.

      My advice. Do what you should, pay what you should, handle everything legally, and let karma and God handle the rest ;)

Even 13 years from now, when he’s no longer paying…bc then you’ll be thinking about how much further in life you COULD be, how much more STUFF you could have- if he didn’t have to pay ALL THAT CHILD SUPPORT FOR ALL THOSE YEARS.
    This is the life you CHOSE. don’t make your husbands children suffer bc you don’t like how it worked out

    1. alain smithee October 26, 2019 at 6:00 PM

      My state requires both parents to provide copies of their tax returns to the court to verify the parents’ income. If your ex-wife and her new husband aren’t reporting all of their income to the IRS, that creates another set of problems for them, which could cause the courts to give you custody if they are charged with tax fraud.

Not fair, makes it easy for a parent to live a good life for minimum 18 years. Why can’t I have extra cash to take my son to a amusement park but she can? I want that memory too your honor. I was also told by my lawyer this system is set so the child lives equally in both homes. Lol…yeah, we live equal. She has a 2 bedroom apt while I am forced to share a room with my son. I had a beautiful 2 bedroom condo for 8 years previous to making the wrong decision with this lady. No regrets though because she birthed me an amazing son. Not saying this is what all women do because there are many that deserve the support because Dad is a bum but I’m sure there are plenty that have multiple kids because how the system is set up which makes them a certified bum. Feel bad for a millionaire. Boy they get hustled. What’s fair is let the child see how a parent works hard to provide and not one suffer from the system. That’s living equal!!! If Mom or Dad isn’t motivated to do better in life, that’s their fault. For now my son will look at mom as the bread winner taking him out buying him clothes, prettying up herself, while Dad lives conservative until he’s nearly 60. If Dad makes more money, mom gets more? How is that fair? Now there are women on the opposite side of this argument that have to pay dad and it’s unfair to them too so don’t take this as a male chauvinist point of view. Bottom line is simple, you have a child and can’t be a grown up to stay together for the better of the family, then you pay for the care of the child on your time no excuses. Make the law like this and watch how many more families try to make it work things out instead of splitting up because they know the system has their back. Watch how families work together. Guess the system would rather benefit with court costs, monthly processing fees, mediation services, court paper document fees instead of seeing families together. That’s the America we live in. I think this topic needs revisited and hopefully a go fund me page will be created to buy the best attorney team to take this out of the states hands and squash that ridiculous percentage of your income rule and at least come with a fair weekly cost for all no matter of your status quo. God help us all!

About

Created in 2008, J. Money started the blog to hold himself accountable and have some fun talking about money in the process. An avid coin collector, yogi, and Daddy x3 (boys), you can find him trying to live his Best Life while sharing all his wins (and fails!) in the process. Thanks for being here! [Full Bio]
